script: They will send you back to die, like the bastards always do.
You're being released from detention. Today if you're lucky.
This is bail, Mr. and Mrs. Majur.
You're being released on bail as asylum seekers.
Until then, you'll be subject to certain conditions.
If you fail to meet these, even just the once, you'll be returned to detention.
Your case may be disqualified and you'll be sent back.
You will be reviewed and must report to us weekly.
You must not miss a single report.
A yes, if you understand, please.
You will be given financial weekly support of 74 pounds in total.
You do not have permission to work or to supplement your earnings by any other means.
A yes, if you understand, please.
Final condition. You will be sent to a home of our choosing.
You must reside at this address.
You must not move from this address.
Whether or not you're good people, it's not me that needs convincing.
Normally, it should be half the size with twice as many of you in it, but...
This is... this is all for you.
All right, a few ground rules.
Uh... no candles, no smoking, no animals.
We'll fix that. No pets, no guests, no friends, no parties.
No ball games, no games, no balls.
Get some screws for your door. There's a shop round the corner.
Uh, say hello to your neighbors and that, and...
Didn't have time to get the cleaners, but...
There's a doctor down the road.
I wouldn't worry about the smell.
Open a window, the place should air out.
A new beginning starts with a single step, innit?
-Eh? -This entire house is just for us?
I think you two are gonna be all right.
As long as you can get along, fit in.
-We are not going back. -That's the spirit.
Be one of the good ones.
You were singing songs about this Peter Crouch?
I think it is the worst song I've ever heard.
-I don't want you to have one, anyway. -Them chips are wet, bruv.
-What the fuck are you doing? -What's all this?
-Chat to her, bro. -Aw, you need to chat to her, bruv.
But anyways, it's that side, I think, on the left.
-Bruv, what are you talkin' about? -What do you mean?
Take this left here, walk all the way down to the end.
-It's just on the right hand side, yeah? -Are you nuts?
-Nah, it's like, down there, by the bank. -Yeah.
-Oh! No, no, no, he's right still. -Is he?
No, he's right still. Yeah, sorry, my bad. No, it is. Head back that way.
-It's just by the bank, yeah. -You sure?
Go back to Africa. Only English around here, darlin'.
Oh, is that your daughter? Mine's a real handful.
You registered her yet? We should take a look at her, too.
These I've had since I was a little girl.
These I gave to myself with a knife.
When I found my family butchered.
There are two tribes where I'm from.
Depending on which one you belong to, you mark yourself.
I think there's someone living there.
But maybe next time, we can use the table.
All I can taste is the metal.
You will get used to it.
They give you a chance here.
My mother used to tell me a story.
In our village, there was once an honorable but poor man who wanted a home of his own.
He wanted it so badly, he began to steal from others.
he stole from an old man who lived by the river.
He didn't know that this man was an apeth.
And so the thief could not know that when he built his home...
the apeth, too, would live there.
So, before long, the walls would whisper the spells of the apeth.
until he had consumed the man entirely.
An apeth has arisen from the ocean.
...it would guide us back to her.
-I will speak my mother's language. -Listen to what you are saying.
I had assured myself it was a dream.
But now I have looked into your eyes.
-Everything we brought is cursed. -Bol, what are you doing?
What are you doing? Leave it! Stop!
What do you mean marked? What did you see?
-Oh... Why? Don't! -Let-- Perhaps if you spoke to him...
Perhaps you think we're going mad.
I think it's not healthy for you to be alone all the time.
Tomorrow, we will find you something to do.
-We are not like them. -We can be.
You don't wonder what it tells me?
Frightening yourself with imaginary things in the dark.
After all we've endured, after what we have seen...
what men can do, you think it is bumps in the night that frighten me?
You think I can be afraid of ghosts?
It says I can get her back.
And it says I should be afraid of you.
Adam, uh... do you wanna get him some juice?
You havin' problems with the property?
Sure, yeah, we can look into that for you.
But first, you have to tell me why.
I mean, can you name me one of the problems?
this is gonna raise a lot of questions... Bol.
They're gonna ask you why you're not adapting.
I used to work in a bank, too, believe it not, back in the day, before they moved all the jobs...
I think that's life trying to show you what kind of man you are.
Do you know what I'm sayin'?
I'm tryin' to work out what kind of man you are, Bol.
I just need a new house.
Look at the state of you. You're a mess. You don't look well, mate, you look ill.
You don't smell good. You smell bad.
You're not making any sense. It would have to be reported. And then...
people, not me, but people are then gonna ask, Why is he bitin' the hand that's feedin' him?
-We can live anywhere else. -There's rats everywhere.
-Anywhere else. -Oh, right. So it's not about the rats.
Can't be that bad, you're laughin'.
If you want me to make a fuss, mate, I will make a fuss.
-Yes! -If you want me to do it, then I will.
They're gonna kick you out anyway.
Well, I'm... I'm gonna have to report it now.
No, I'm gonna have to. I'm gonna have to take photos.
We are one of the good ones. Remember?
Mr. Majur, we will let you off with a warning this time.
-Hang-- hang on a minute. -Let me deal with it.
There's a great beast in this house.
My husband's been chasing it all night with a hammer.
It's filling this house with ghosts.
It torments my husband with visits from her.
But my husband is a very stubborn man.
He still believes he can deny it.
You should put that into your report.
They don't want to be reminded that it is them that are weak.
And then you thank them for the unseasoned scraps they throw us.
I'm leaving. With or without you.
How quickly you forget everything we went through to get here.
How quickly you forget our daugh-- You are sick.
This time, you talk to me.
No matter where you go, I follow.
Take this knife and open your flesh.
Why don't you come for me yourself?
You can't touch me. You can't hurt me.
Make yourself at home. Pictures can't hurt me.
Pictures can't hurt me. Pictures can't hurt me.
Look at me. Look. Look at me.
Now. We have to go. Come.
Please, please, please, please. Rial. Please. Rial.
-Come, come forward. -We are going to make space.
-You have space for two more? -Too many. No.
Two more! Two more! Two more!
-No, no, no! You wait! -No, sir. No, sir.
-I said children. You are not a child. -Wait-- No! We have to go! We have to go!
-No! -She-- She's a child! She's a child!
and I will give you what you want.
And what does that make us?
Hello, Rial. Sorry to bother you.
Uh, we work with Mark. May we come in?
I think I might paint this room red.
It's when I let them in, I could start to face myself.
Thank you, Mr. and Mrs. Majur.
